choices.text: In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur has a lower pitch
In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur is of the crescendo type
In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur has a softer intensity
In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur has a briefer duration

questions.text: How does the murmur of severe aortic regurgitation differ from that of mild aortic regurgitation? ( NEET PG 2015 )
questions.solution:
Ans. D) In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur has a briefer duration

 

Explanation: 

 

The murmur associated with severe aortic regurgitation is significantly shorter in duration compared to the murmur of mild aortic regurgitation. In mild cases, the regurgitant murmur is longer because the pressure gradient between the aorta and left ventricle takes more time to equalize. However, as the severity of the regurgitation increases, this pressure equalization occurs more rapidly, resulting in a markedly shortened murmur duration.

 

While the intensity of the murmur may increase slightly with severe regurgitation, the most notable difference lies in the considerably reduced duration of the murmur. Regardless of severity, the typical aortic regurgitation murmur is a high-pitched, early diastolic, decrescendo murmur best heard at Erb's point (the third intercostal space on the left) with the patient sitting up, leaning forward, and at end-expiration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The pitch of the aortic regurgitation murmur remains high regardless of severity.

 

Option B. Aortic regurgitation murmurs are decrescendo (diminishing) in character, not crescendo (increasing).

 

Option C. The intensity of the murmur may actually increase slightly with severe regurgitation, not become softer.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Severe aortic regurgitation is characterized by a significantly shorter murmur duration compared to mild aortic regurgitation due to the rapid equalization of pressure between the aorta and left ventricle.

choices.text: Chest wall neuromuscular disease
Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis

questions.text: The given image shows a normal graph on the left and the patient's graph on the right. Which of the following diagnoses can be inferred from the graph? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bronchiectasis

 

Explanation:  

 

The spirometry graph compares a normal patient's lung function with that of the patient. The normal graph shows an FEV1/FVC ratio (Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second / Forced Vital Capacity) of more than 70%, which is typical in healthy individuals. In contrast, the patient's graph shows a significantly reduced FEV1/FVC ratio of approximately 50-55%, indicating an obstructive lung disease.

 

Obstructive lung diseases are characterized by reduced airflow due to airway narrowing or obstruction, leading to a lower FEV1/FVC ratio. The common obstructive lung diseases include asthma, emphysema, chronic bronchitis, COPD, bronchiectasis, and cystic fibrosis. Among the given options, bronchiectasis is the only obstructive lung disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chest wall neuromuscular disease: This typically causes restrictive lung disease, not obstructive, and would present with a normal or high FEV1/FVC ratio but reduced lung volumes.

 

Option B. Sarcoidosis: This is an interstitial lung disease, which is restrictive. It would show a normal or elevated FEV1/FVC ratio with reduced lung volumes.

 

Option C. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis: Another interstitial lung disease leading to restrictive patterns on spirometry, characterized by a normal or high FEV1/FVC ratio with reduced total lung capacity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A reduced FEV1/FVC ratio (<70%) is indicative of obstructive lung disease. Among the given options, bronchiectasis is the obstructive lung disease associated with this spirometry pattern.

choices.text: Lifestyle modification and weight loss
Ursodeoxycholic acid and lifestyle modification
Lifestyle modifications and vitamin E
Pioglitazone and lifestyle modifications

questions.text: A patient with a history of consumption of 2-3 drinks per week comes with complaints of right upper quadrant discomfort. He has grade 2 steatosis. His BMI was 29 kg/m² and AST and ALT levels were slightly elevated. What would you advise him? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lifestyle modification and weight loss

 

Explanation:  

 

The patient is likely suffering from non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), specifically non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), given his history of minimal alcohol consumption, grade 2 steatosis, elevated BMI, and mildly elevated liver enzymes (AST and ALT). The cornerstone of treatment for NASH is lifestyle modification and weight loss. These interventions help reduce liver fat, inflammation, and fibrosis. No FDA-approved medications currently exist for the treatment of NASH; thus, lifestyle changes are the primary recommended approach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ursodeoxycholic acid and lifestyle modification: Ursodeoxycholic acid is used for primary biliary cholangitis, not NASH, and thus is not appropriate here.

 

Option C. Lifestyle modifications and vitamin E: Vitamin E can be used off-label in non-diabetic patients with NASH but is not FDA-approved or considered first-line treatment. It can be considered but is secondary to lifestyle changes.

 

Option D. Pioglitazone and lifestyle modifications: Pioglitazone, along with other medications like metformin and GLP-1 receptor agonists, is sometimes used off-label for diabetic patients with NASH. However, it is not FDA-approved for NASH and should not be the first-line recommendation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lifestyle modification and weight loss are the primary and most effective treatments for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), as no FDA-approved medications are currently available for this condition.

questions.text: A 53-year-old gentleman presents with chest pain which is happening at rest. Pain is persistent for 3-5 minutes and he is having recurrent pain over the last 48 hours and he used 3 puffs of GTN to relieve his pain. His current medications include GTN PRN, Atorvastatin 20mg HS, Metoprolol 50mg BID, and Aspirin 75mg OD. His troponin was negative and ECG showed LVH with flattening of the ST segment. What is the most appropriate next step in management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Start enoxaparin 1mg/kg s.c BD

 

The patient is presenting with symptoms suggestive of unstable angina, given the recurrent chest pain at rest and ECG changes (left ventricular hypertrophy with ST segment flattening). Despite the negative troponin, which rules out myocardial infarction, the clinical scenario points to a high risk of acute coronary syndrome (ACS).

 

For high-risk ACS, especially in a patient already on medications for coronary artery disease (CAD) like aspirin, atorvastatin, and metoprolol, initiating anticoagulation therapy is crucial to prevent thrombus formation and progression to myocardial infarction. Enoxaparin, a low molecular weight heparin, is recommended at a therapeutic dose of 1 mg/kg subcutaneously twice a day to achieve effective anticoagulation in this setting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Add long-acting nitrate: While long-acting nitrates can help with angina symptoms, they are not the primary treatment for acute management in this scenario. The priority is to stabilize the patient and prevent further thrombotic events.

 

Option B. Increase metoprolol dose to 100mg BID: Increasing the dose of metoprolol may help with angina control, but it does not address the underlying risk of thrombus formation and is not the immediate next step in managing high-risk unstable angina.

 

Option C. Add clopidogrel 75mg OD: Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet agent that is beneficial in ACS, but in this acute setting, starting anticoagulation with enoxaparin takes precedence to prevent thrombus formation. Clopidogrel can be added as part of dual antiplatelet therapy later on.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with high-risk unstable angina, especially those with recurrent chest pain at rest and ECG changes, initiating therapeutic anticoagulation with enoxaparin is a critical step in the acute management to prevent thrombus formation and progression to myocardial infarction.

choices.text: Must be distinguished from Pulsus Alternans
Is a sign of digitalis toxicity

questions.text: All of the following statements about Pulsus Bigeminus are true, except? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Compensatory pause is absent

 

Explanation:

 

Pulsus bigeminus is characterized by a normal beat followed by a premature ventricular contraction (PVC), creating a pattern where every other beat appears weaker. This creates an alternating strong-weak pulse pattern. Importantly, PVCs typically have a compensatory pause following them, as the ventricle is refractory to the next normal sinus impulse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Must be distinguished from Pulsus Alternans:  Pulsus bigeminus must be distinguished from pulsus alternans as they present differently. Pulsus alternans is associated with severe left ventricular dysfunction, while pulsus bigeminus is due to premature beats.

 

Option B. Is a sign of digitalis toxicity: Digitalis toxicity can produce various dysrhythmias including premature ventricular contractions in a bigeminal pattern. It's a classic manifestation of digoxin toxicity.

 

Option D. Rhythm is irregular: Pulsus bigeminus demonstrates an irregular rhythm with normal sinus beats interrupted by premature ventricular contractions.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Pulsus bigeminus is an irregular cardiac rhythm characterized by normal beats alternating with premature ventricular contractions, which are typically followed by compensatory pauses as the ventricle is refractory to the next sinus impulse.

questions.text: Which part of the internal capsule is affected in hemiplegia due to ischemic stroke? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior Limb

 

The posterior limb of the internal capsule is the most commonly affected area in cases of hemiplegia due to ischemic stroke. This area carries the corticospinal tract, which is essential for motor control. When the posterior limb is compromised, it disrupts the corticospinal pathway, leading to muscle weakness or paralysis on the opposite side of the body from the lesion.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrolentiform: Primarily involved in visual processing. Damage here would likely lead to visual field defects rather than motor dysfunction.

 

Option B. Anterior limb: Primarily associated with cognitive and emotional functions due to its connectivity between the thalamus and the frontal lobe. Lesions here generally do not cause hemiplegia.

 

Option C. Sublentiform: Involved in auditory and gustatory pathways, thus unrelated to motor control functions affected in hemiplegia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of ischemic stroke, damage to the posterior limb of the internal capsule results in hemiplegia because of the disruption of corticospinal tracts. This knowledge aids in accurate stroke localization and informs rehabilitation strategies to help regain motor functions.

questions.text: Which of the following is a PCSK-9 inhibitor?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Evolocumab

 

PCSK-9 inhibitors are a class of drugs that significantly lower LDL cholesterol levels by inhibiting the protein PCSK-9, which in turn increases the number of LDL receptors available to clear LDL cholesterol from the blood.

 

There are only 2 PCSK-9 inhibitors: Evolocumab and alirocumab. Among the options provided:

 

Evolocumab is a well-known PCSK-9 inhibitor used in modern clinical practice to manage hyperlipidemia, particularly in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia or those who are at high risk of cardiovascular events.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe is an NPC1L1 transport inhibitor, also known as an intestinal cholesterol absorption inhibitor. It reduces blood cholesterol by decreasing the absorption of cholesterol in the small intestine.

 

Option C. Evinacumab: Evinacumab is a newer drug that acts as an ANGPTL3 inhibitor. It is specifically approved for use in patients with familial homozygous type 2 hyperlipidemia.

 

Option D. Everolimus: Everolimus is an mTOR inhibitor and an immunosuppressive drug used primarily in organ transplantation and certain types of cancer. It is not related to the treatment of dyslipidemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Evolocumab is a PCSK-9 inhibitor used to significantly lower LDL cholesterol levels, particularly in high-risk patients.

questions.text: A patient was admitted to the casualty with hysteria and anxiety. Estimation of arterial plasma showed pH of 7.53; HCO₃ of 18 meq and Pco₂ of 27 mm Hg. Which of the following is the patient’s primary disorder? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Respiratory alkalosis

 

Explanation:

 

The arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis suggests that the primary acid-base disorder is respiratory alkalosis. Here’s a step-by-step approach to determine the disorder:

 

  1. Assess the pH:
    • Normal pH: 7.35 – 7.45
    • Patient’s pH: 7.53 (indicates alkalosis)
  2. Determine the primary disturbance:
    • pCO₂ (Respiratory Component):
      • Normal range: 35 – 45 mm Hg
      • Patient’s pCO₂: 27 mm Hg (decreased, indicates alkalosis)
      • Since the pCO₂ is decreased and corresponds with the alkaline pH, the primary disorder is respiratory.
    • HCO₃ (Metabolic Component):
      • Normal range: 22 – 28 meq/L
      • Patient’s HCO₃: 18 meq/L (decreased, indicates acidosis)
      • The decreased HCO₃ does not align with the alkaline pH, indicating it is a compensatory response.
  3. Conclude the diagnosis:
    • Primary disorder: Respiratory alkalosis (due to decreased pCO₂)
    • Compensatory mechanism: Metabolic acidosis (decreased HCO₃)
  4. Therefore, the primary disorder is respiratory alkalosis with a compensatory metabolic acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metabolic acidosis: This would present with a low pH (< 7.35) and decreased HCO₃.

 

Option B. Metabolic alkalosis: This would present with an increased pH (> 7.45) and increased HCO₃.

 

Option C. Respiratory acidosis: This would present with a low pH (< 7.35) and increased pCO₂.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary disorder is determined by the component (pCO₂ or HCO₃) that aligns with the pH. In this case, respiratory alkalosis is indicated by decreased pCO₂ and an increased pH.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female patient came to the outpatient department with complaints of neck swelling. She gives a history of weight loss and palpitations. On examination, she has exophthalmos and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland. What are the essential investigations that should be done for the patient? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Thyroid scan
  2. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC)
  3. Thyroid function tests
  4. Ultrasound of neck
  5. Anti-thyroid antibody
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4, and 5 only

 

The clinical presentation of neck swelling, weight loss, palpitations, exophthalmos, and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland suggests hyperthyroidism, likely Graves' disease.

 

FNAC is not recommended in this case because it does not provide additional diagnostic yield for Graves' disease, does not alter the treatment plan, and carries a risk of complications due to the gland's increased vascularity in Graves' disease.

 

Other Options:

 

The following investigations are essential:

 

1. Thyroid scan: A radioactive iodine uptake scan helps differentiate between diffuse uptake (indicative of Graves' disease) and nodular uptake (indicative of toxic multinodular goiter or Plummer's disease).

 

3. Thyroid function tests: These are crucial as they provide information on the levels of thyroid hormones (T3, T4) and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), helping confirm the diagnosis of hyperthyroidism.

 

4. Ultrasound of neck: This imaging modality helps assess the thyroid gland's structure and can reveal increased vascularity, which is characteristic of Graves' disease.

 

5. Anti-thyroid antibody: Testing for antibodies, such as TSH receptor antibodies (TRAbs) or thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI), is important for diagnosing autoimmune thyroid diseases like Graves' disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with clinical signs of hyperthyroidism and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland, essential investigations include a thyroid scan, thyroid function tests, ultrasound of the neck, and anti-thyroid antibody tests. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is not typically required in these cases.

choices.text: Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) at 24 hours above normal

questions.text: A middle-aged woman who presented with fatigue, dry skin, weight gain, and menstrual irregularities is diagnosed with Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Which of the following statements would be correct with respect to her thyroid function test? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ana. A) High TSH levels

 

Explanation:

 

Hashimoto’s thyroiditis is an autoimmune condition resulting in hypothyroidism due to destruction of thyroid tissue. Key thyroid function test findings include:

 

  • High TSH levels: As thyroid hormone (T3, T4) levels decline, the pituitary gland increases TSH secretion to stimulate the thyroid.
  • Low free T4 and T3 levels: Reflecting decreased thyroid hormone production.
  • RAIU at 24 hours below normal: Thyroid destruction leads to reduced iodine uptake.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. High free T4 levels: Incorrect because free T4 is typically low in hypothyroidism due to reduced thyroid hormone production.

 

Option C. High serum T3 levels: Incorrect because T3 levels are also reduced in hypothyroidism, though they may decline later than T4.

 

Option D. RAIU at 24 hours above normal: Incorrect because iodine uptake is reduced in Hashimoto's thyroiditis due to thyroid destruction, unlike hyperthyroid states like Graves' disease where uptake is increased.

 

Educational Objective:


In Hashimoto’s thyroiditis, high TSH levels reflect the pituitary’s attempt to compensate for decreased thyroid hormone levels, a hallmark of hypothyroidism. RAIU is typically reduced due to thyroid destruction. Early detection and appropriate thyroid hormone replacement can prevent complications.

questions.text: What subtype of Bartter’s syndrome is linked to barttin mutations? NEET 2016:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Type 4

 

Explanation:

 

Type 4 Bartter’s syndrome is specifically associated with mutations in the barttin protein. This type of the syndrome is characterized by the presence of sensorineural deafness alongside the typical symptoms of Bartter’s syndrome such as salt-wasting and hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis. Barttin is an essential subunit that supports the function of chloride channels, crucial for ion transport processes in the kidney. Mutations here disrupt these processes significantly, mimicking the effects of loop diuretics and leading to the severe manifestation of symptoms seen in this subtype.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1: Incorrect because it involves mutations in the Na-K-2Cl pump, not barttin.

 

Option B. Type 2: Incorrect as it involves mutations in the ROMK potassium channel, unrelated to barttin.

 

Option C. Type 3: Incorrect since it is associated with mutations in the chloride channel ClC-Kb, distinct from barttin mutations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type 4 Bartter’s syndrome is the subtype associated with mutations in barttin and is accompanied by sensorineural deafness.

questions.text:
Which of the following types of headaches requires further evaluation? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Headache for > 4 hours
  2. Worst headache of life
  3. New-onset progressive headache
  4. Headache with blurring of vision
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) 2, 3, 4

 

Certain types of headaches can be indicative of serious underlying conditions and thus require further evaluation to rule out life-threatening or severe pathologies:

 

2. Worst headache of life: This is a classic description of a subarachnoid hemorrhage, which is a medical emergency. Patients experiencing this type of headache require immediate medical attention and thorough investigation, typically involving neuroimaging.

 

3. New-onset progressive headache: Progressive headaches, especially those that are new in onset and occur in adults, raise concern for potential serious conditions such as brain tumors or other intracranial pathologies. These headaches warrant detailed medical evaluation.

 

4. Headache with blurring of vision: This symptom combination suggests possible increased intracranial pressure, which can be associated with conditions like papilledema or optic neuritis. Such cases need prompt assessment to determine the cause and appropriate management.

 

Other Option:

 

1. Headache for > 4 hours: While a headache lasting more than four hours can be distressing, it is not necessarily indicative of a severe underlying condition. Such headaches could be primary headaches like tension-type headaches or migraines, which often do not require immediate further evaluation unless they have other alarming features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Headaches described as the "worst headache of life," new-onset progressive headaches, and headaches accompanied by blurring of vision require further medical evaluation to rule out serious conditions.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with fever, night sweats, ptosis, and bilateral facial nerve palsy. Investigations showed leukocytosis and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sarcoidosis

 

The patient presents with fever, night sweats, ptosis, and bilateral facial nerve palsy. The investigations show leukocytosis and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy.

 

Hilar lymphadenopathy can be seen in many conditions like Sarcoidosis, Pneumoconiosis, TB, etc

 

But the other clinical features point towards sarcoidosis, a systemic inflammatory disease characterized by non-caseating granulomas. Sarcoidosis can affect multiple organs, but it commonly involves the lungs and lymph nodes. Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy is a hallmark finding in sarcoidosis and is often the first clue in diagnosis. Additionally, sarcoidosis can present with systemic symptoms like fever and night sweats.

 

The presence of bilateral facial nerve palsy is another significant clue. While Guillain-Barre syndrome, Lyme disease, and sarcoidosis can cause bilateral lower motor neuron (LMN) type facial palsy, the combination of other symptoms and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy strongly favors sarcoidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis (TB) can present with fever, night sweats, and lymphadenopathy, including hilar lymphadenopathy. However, TB typically causes caseating granulomas and does not commonly present with bilateral facial nerve palsy.

 

Option C. Lymphoma: Lymphoma can also present with fever, night sweats, and lymphadenopathy. However, it typically involves systemic B symptoms and other lymph node groups. Bilateral facial nerve palsy is not a common presentation of lymphoma.

 

Option D. Hypersensitive pneumonitis: Hypersensitive pneumonitis can present with respiratory symptoms and lymphadenopathy, but it is usually associated with exposure to inhaled organic antigens. It does not typically cause systemic symptoms like fever, night sweats, and bilateral facial nerve palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy with systemic symptoms like fever and night sweats and the presence of bilateral facial nerve palsy is highly suggestive of sarcoidosis. Always consider sarcoidosis first in such clinical scenarios.

questions.text: What part of the brain is primarily damaged in cases of chorea? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Striatum

 

Explanation:

 

Chorea is characterized by rapid, involuntary, and random movements that primarily result from damage to the striatum, a key component of the basal ganglia. The striatum, which includes the caudate nucleus and putamen, plays a critical role in the modulation of movement. Damage or dysfunction in this area disrupts the normal inhibitory and excitatory signals necessary for smooth and controlled motion. This disruption often leads to the characteristic jerky movements associated with chorea. Conditions such as Huntington’s disease, which involve significant degeneration of neuronal cells in the striatum, are classic causes of chorea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subthalamus: Incorrect as lesions here typically result in hemiballismus, not chorea.

 

Option B. Globus pallidus: Incorrect because although it's part of the basal ganglia, damage here is more typically associated with dystonia and athetosis rather than chorea.

 

Option C. Substantia nigra: Incorrect, as damage to this area is primarily associated with Parkinson’s disease, leading to symptoms like bradykinesia and tremor, not chorea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chorea is predominantly due to damage in the striatum, part of the basal ganglia, which leads to uncontrollable, quick movements due to the disruption of motor control

questions.text: Which of the following anticoagulants requires coagulation profile monitoring? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lepirudin

 

Lepirudin is a parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor, which requires routine coagulation profile monitoring. The standard test used for monitoring Lepirudin is the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). In cath labs, when administering in high doses need to be monitor with ACT (Activated Clotting Time) rather than aPTT.

 

This is necessary to ensure the correct therapeutic range is maintained and to avoid complications such as bleeding.

 

Note - There are four parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors: lepirudin, hirudin, bivalirudin, and argatroban.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enoxaparin: Enoxaparin is a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). It has a predictable anticoagulant effect, and routine coagulation monitoring is generally not required under standard clinical circumstances. In special situations, monitoring can be done using anti-factor Xa levels.

 

Option C. Fondaparinux: Fondaparinux, like Enoxaparin, does not typically require routine coagulation monitoring due to its predictable pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics. In specific clinical scenarios, anti-factor Xa levels may be measured.

 

Option D. Dabigatran: Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor and is classified under direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs). Routine coagulation monitoring is not required due to its reliable and predictable effects. However, if monitoring is needed, aPTT can be used, though more specific tests like the dilute thrombin time (dTT) or the ecarin clotting time (ECT) are preferred for accurate measurement.

 

Note - There are four DOACs (Direct Oral Anticoagulants): Dabigatran (direct thrombin inhibitor), Apixaban, Rivaroxaban and Edoxaban (all 3 are factor Xa inhibitor)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lepirudin, a parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor, requires routine coagulation profile monitoring using aPTT to ensure therapeutic efficacy and safety.

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with a unilateral headache. It is associated with nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. What is the best drug for acute management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sumatriptan

 

The patient's symptoms are characteristic of a migraine, which is often associated with unilateral headache, nausea, photophobia (sensitivity to light), and phonophobia (sensitivity to sound).

 

Sumatriptan: This medication is a serotonin receptor agonist (triptan) used for the acute treatment of migraine attacks. It works by stimulating serotonin (5-HT) receptors in the brain, leading to vasoconstriction of dilated blood vessels and relief from migraine symptoms.

 

The best drug for acute management of a migraine attack in this scenario is Sumatriptan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flunarizine: This is a calcium channel blocker used for the prophylactic treatment of migraine, not for acute management.

 

Option C. Propranolol: This beta-blocker is also used for migraine prophylaxis, not for acute attacks.

 

Option D. Topiramate: Used for preventing migraine, not for treating an acute attack.

 

Educaitonal Objective:

 

Sumatriptan is the best medication for the acute management of migraine, characterized by unilateral headache, nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best treatment for idiopathic thrombocytic purpura? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Splenectomy

 

Splenectomy is considered the best long-term treatment option for patients with chronic ITP who do not respond to medical therapies such as steroids or immunoglobulins. The procedure involves removing the spleen, which is a site of platelet destruction in ITP. Removing the spleen often results in a permanent increase in platelet count, though it is typically reserved for patients who are refractory to first-line treatments.

 

Approach to ITP:

 

If severe ITP @ presentation: Transfusion+ steroids

 

  • Intracranial/GI Bleed
  • PC < 5k
  • Large oral bleed/Retinal bleed

 

Low dose steroids recommended in all cases of ITP.

 

If steroid unresponsive, decision depends on duration:

 

  1. Persistent (3-12 months): Rituximab vs TPO-RA (Romiplostim (S. C.), Eltrombopag (Oral)
  2. Chronic (>12 months): Rituximab vs Splenectomy vs TPO-RA

 

If still persistent/refractory, possible options are:

 

  • Fostamatinib: SyK (Tyrosine kinase inhibitor)
  • MMF/Cyclophosphamide/Azathioprine
  • Autologous stem cell transplant

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV immunoglobulins: Used as a first-line treatment, especially for acute cases of ITP or in severe cases to quickly raise the platelet count, but not as a long-term solution.

 

Option B. Steroids: Common first-line treatment for ITP that can effectively increase platelet count in many patients, though many eventually relapse upon discontinuation or become steroid-dependent.

 

Option D. Blood transfusion: Generally not a primary treatment for ITP since the issue is not the quantity of produced platelets but their premature destruction; transfusions might be used in acute, severe bleeding scenarios but do not address the underlying autoimmune process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Splenectomy is often considered the best treatment option for chronic or refractory idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura, particularly when other treatments such as steroids and IV immunoglobulins fail to maintain a safe platelet count or cause side effects that are difficult to manage.

 

Reference: ASH 2021 summary

choices.text: Descending paralysis is seen
Plasmapheresis is a treatment method

questions.text: All are true about Typical Guillain-Barre syndrome except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Descending paralysis is seen

 

Guillain-Barre Syndrome (GBS) is typically characterized by ascending paralysis, starting from the lower extremities and moving upward, not descending paralysis. This pattern begins with weakness in the legs that spreads to the upper limbs and the face, associated with the demyelination of peripheral nerves. The condition is indeed inflammatory and primarily affects the peripheral nervous system, leading to demyelination and sometimes axonal damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inflammatory condition: True, GBS is an acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy.

 

Option C. Plasmapheresis is a treatment method: True, plasmapheresis is used to remove antibodies from the blood that are thought to be involved in the immune attack on the peripheral nerves.

 

Option D. Demyelinating disorder: True, GBS involves the demyelination of peripheral nerves, leading to muscle weakness and paralysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GBS produces neuro-radiculopathy due to demyelination causing ascending paralysis.

 

Causes of Descending paralysis (Mnemonic: Bipolar disorder [BPD]):

 

B: Botulism

P: Porphyria, Polio

D: Diphtheria

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents to you with fever, breathlessness, and cough with expectoration. A CT scan was done which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Consolidation

 

The patient's symptoms of fever, breathlessness, and cough with expectoration suggest an infectious process in the lungs. The CT scan provided shows a large area of increased density (whitish patch) in the right lung, particularly in the lower lobe. This area is accompanied by air bronchograms, which are dark branching structures representing air-filled bronchi within the consolidated lung tissue. The presence of air bronchograms is a classic sign of consolidation, which indicates that the alveoli are filled with inflammatory exudates, cells, or other materials, typically due to pneumonia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mass: A mass would appear as a localized, well-defined lesion in the lung tissue without the characteristic air bronchograms seen in consolidation. It would not typically present with diffuse symptoms like those described (fever, breathlessness, and productive cough).

 

Option C. Pleural Effusion: Pleural effusion involves the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space surrounding the lungs. On imaging, it appears as a homogenous opacity at the lung base with a meniscus sign. It does not show air bronchograms and typically does not present with the same radiographic features as consolidation.

 

Option D. Diaphragmatic Hernia: A diaphragmatic hernia involves the protrusion of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity through a defect in the diaphragm. This condition would appear on imaging as abdominal organs (e.g., intestines) within the chest cavity, not as a consolidation pattern with air bronchograms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Consolidation in the lung, often due to pneumonia, is characterized by a homogenous area of increased density with air bronchograms on imaging, and presents with symptoms such as fever, breathlessness, and productive cough.

questions.text: Identify the urinary crystal shown below? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcium oxalate


Calcium oxalate crystals are typically bipyramidal or envelope-shaped. These crystals are common in various conditions, including hyperoxaluria and ethylene glycol poisoning.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Calcium phosphate:  crystals form asymmetric rosettes.

 

Option C. Uric acid:  crystals are rhomboid forming rosettes, polychromatophilic in Polarized Microscope.

 

Option D. Cystine:  crystals are hexagonal, and one of the hardest crystals.

 

Note - Monohydrate crystal – dumbbell shaped

 

Educational Objective:

 

Calcium oxalate crystals are bipyramidal or envelope-shaped.

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient presented with spikes of fever and difficulty in breathing. Transesophageal echo revealed vegetations in the heart. The culture was positive for Burkholderia cepacia. Which of the following is the first line of management? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cotrimoxazole with 3rd generation cephalosporins

 

The correct answer is B, Cotrimoxazole with 3rd generation cephalosporins. This combination is effective against Burkholderia cepacia, a pathogen known for its resistance to many standard antibiotics. The standard regimen includes Cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole), which has broad-spectrum bacterial coverage, combined with a 3rd generation cephalosporin such as ceftazidime or cefoperazone-sulbactam to cover for the pathogen's unique resistance profiles and aggressive infection nature, especially in immunocompromised patients or those with existing cardiac issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aminoglycoside and colistin: This option is incorrect due to the intrinsic resistance of Burkholderia cepacia to aminoglycosides. While colistin could still be effective, the resistance to aminoglycosides limits this combination's usefulness.

 

Option C. Carbapenems and 3rd generation cephalosporin: Incorrect because the combination of carbapenems with cephalosporins is generally not recommended. They both share a similar mechanism of action, inhibiting bacterial cell wall synthesis, and could potentially compete for the same binding sites, thus reducing their effectiveness.

 

Option D. Cefepime and tigecycline: Incorrect because tigecycline is not particularly effective against Burkholderia cepacia. Cefepime alone would not sufficiently manage the infection due to the bacteria's robust resistance profile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The standard regimen for Burkholderia cepacia is cotrimoxazole with ceftazidime /cefoperazone-sulbactam.

questions.text: A elderly patient presents with cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy. Which investigation should be performed next to help you diagnose the condition? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. ANCA

 

The clinical features of cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy are suggestive of a systemic vasculitis affecting small vessels. Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are associated with certain types of small vessel vasculitis, making ANCA testing the next appropriate step in the diagnostic process. The presence of ANCA, depending on its pattern—c-ANCA typically associated with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener’s granulomatosis) and p-ANCA with microscopic polyangiitis and Churg-Strauss syndrome—helps in confirming the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RA factor: Although rheumatoid factor (RA factor) can be elevated in conditions like mixed cryoglobulinemia, which might present similarly, it is less specific for diagnosing small vessel vasculitis compared to ANCA.

 

Option C. HbsAg: Hepatitis B surface antigen (HbsAg) could be relevant if considering hepatitis B associated vasculitis, but given the clinical presentation, it is less likely the cause of these symptoms.

 

Option D. DIF (Direct Immunofluorescence): While useful in diagnosing immune complex deposition diseases such as immune-complex mediated vasculitis, it is not as directly diagnostic of ANCA-associated vasculitis as ANCA testing itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Features are suggestive of small vessel vasculitis.

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Vasculitis syndrome/Chap 363

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department after ingesting an unknown quantity of amitriptyline tablets. He develops confusion, seizures, and wide QRS complexes on ECG. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sodium bicarbonate

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation suggests amitriptyline toxicity, a tricyclic antidepressant overdose. Amitriptyline overdose is known to cause:

  • Confusion and seizures: Due to central nervous system toxicity.
  • Wide QRS complexes on ECG: A hallmark of sodium channel blockade, which can lead to life-threatening arrhythmias.

Sodium bicarbonate is the treatment of choice for tricyclic antidepressant overdose with wide QRS complexes. It works by:

  1. Alkalinizing the blood: Reduces binding of the drug to sodium channels.
  2. Increasing extracellular sodium: Helps overcome the sodium channel blockade, stabilizing cardiac membranes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. N-acetylcysteine: Incorrect because it is the antidote for paracetamol toxicity, not for tricyclic antidepressant overdose.

 

Option C. Ursodeoxycholic acid: Incorrect because it is used in cholestatic liver diseases and has no role in managing tricyclic toxicity.

 

Option D. Dopamine: Incorrect because it is used to improve renal perfusion in shock and does not address sodium channel blockade or arrhythmias caused by amitriptyline.

 

Educational Objective:


Sodium bicarbonate is the first-line treatment for tricyclic antidepressant overdose with cardiotoxicity, such as wide QRS complexes. Early recognition and treatment are essential to prevent life-threatening arrhythmias and seizures.

questions.text: All of the following are features of ulcerative colitis except: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Transmural involvement

 

Explanation:

 

Incorrect because transmural inflammation is a hallmark of Crohn's disease, not UC.


Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease characterized by the following:

  • Lead pipe appearance: A classic radiological feature due to loss of haustral folds, typically seen in chronic UC.
  • Continuous involvement: Inflammation in UC is continuous, starting from the rectum and extending proximally in a uniform pattern, unlike the skip lesions of Crohn's disease.
  • Rectal involvement: The rectum is almost always involved in UC.

UC is limited to the mucosa and submucosa, and it does not involve the entire thickness (transmural involvement) of the bowel wall, unlike Crohn's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lead pipe appearance: Correct for UC, reflecting chronic inflammation and fibrosis.

 

Option B. Continuous involvement: Correct because UC has a uniform pattern of inflammation without skip lesions.

 

Option D. Rectal involvement: Correct because UC typically involves the rectum.

 

Educational Objective:


Ulcerative colitis is characterized by continuous inflammation limited to the mucosa and submucosa, often with rectal involvement and a "lead pipe appearance" on imaging. Transmural involvement is a distinguishing feature of Crohn's disease

questions.text: A patient after RTA (Road Traffic Accident) presented with hypovolemic shock. What is the reason for decreased cardiac output in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased preload

 

Hypovolemic shock, often caused by significant blood loss as in the case of a road traffic accident (RTA), leads to a decrease in the volume of blood returning to the heart (preload). Preload is the initial stretching of the cardiac myocytes prior to contraction, which is directly related to the volume of blood filling the heart. When there is a significant loss of blood volume, the preload decreases, leading to a reduced stroke volume and, consequently, decreased cardiac output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased afterload: This refers to the resistance the heart must overcome to eject blood. Increased afterload is not a primary issue in hypovolemic shock.

 

Option C. High systemic vascular resistance: This would be more characteristic of distributive shock, such as septic shock, rather than hypovolemic shock.

 

Option D. Decreased contractility: While decreased contractility can reduce cardiac output, in hypovolemic shock, the primary problem is the loss of blood volume leading to decreased preload, not a primary issue with the heart muscle's ability to contract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hypovolemic shock, the primary cause of decreased cardiac output is decreased preload due to significant loss of blood volume.

questions.text: Dialysis will prevent all except? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peripheral Neuropathy

 

Dialysis is effective in removing many waste products and toxins from the blood, which can alleviate a range of symptoms associated with uremia. However, it is less effective in preventing or reversing complications that arise from the accumulation of middle molecular weight substances, such as those implicated in peripheral neuropathy.

 

 

Peripheral neuropathy in dialysis patients is largely attributed to the build-up of middle molecular weight molecules like beta 2 microglobulin, which are not efficiently removed by standard dialysis membranes. Native kidneys or high-flux dialyzers are more effective at removing these molecules, but even these can have limited efficacy. Peripheral neuropathy is thus a complication less responsive to conventional dialysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seizures: These are often caused by severe uremia or electrolyte imbalances, both of which can be effectively managed through dialysis.

 

Option B. Metabolic acidosis: Dialysis helps correct metabolic acidosis by removing excess acids from the blood and restoring bicarbonate levels.

 

Option D. Uremic pericarditis: Uremic toxins that contribute to inflammatory conditions such as pericarditis are effectively removed through dialysis, thereby preventing this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While dialysis effectively manages many complications of renal failure such as seizures, metabolic acidosis, and uremic pericarditis, it is less effective for peripheral neuropathy due to its limited ability to remove middle molecular weight toxins that contribute to nerve damage. Ongoing management and treatment strategies need to consider these limitations.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Nephrology, Dialysis

questions.text: A 25yr old woman came to OPD one year after the birth of her last child. She had been treated for iron deficiency anemia while pregnant. On examination, she is pale, and investigations show a HB of 5mg/dl and a reticulocyte count of 9%. What is her corrected reticulocyte count ? (take normal Hb as 15mg/dl) (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3

 

Corrected reticulocyte count (CRC)= reticulocyte % X (actual Hb/normal Hb)

 

CRC= 9 X 5/15 = 3%

 

CRC can also be calculated using hematocrit

 

CRC= Reticulocyte % X (Actual PCV/ normal PCV )

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corrected reticulocyte count (CRC) adjusts the observed reticulocyte percentage to reflect the degree of anemia by using the patient's actual hemoglobin compared to a normal hemoglobin level.

 

The corrected reticulocyte count is crucial for assessing bone marrow response in anemic patients, providing insight into whether the bone marrow is responding appropriately to the anemia. This is particularly important in managing patients with iron deficiency anemia to monitor recovery or response to therapy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with 15 days of fever and altered sensorium for 1 day. A rapid diagnostic test was done, and Plasmodium falciparum was diagnosed. Which of the following is not a complication? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arterial pH >7.2

 

An arterial pH >7.2, however, is not considered a complication of severe malaria. In fact, severe acidosis is defined by an arterial pH of less than 7.25, and it is a sign of severe malaria. Therefore, an arterial pH >7.2 does not indicate severe malaria.

 

Other Options:

 

Plasmodium falciparum malaria is a severe form of malaria that can lead to numerous complications. The World Health Organization (WHO) defines several criteria for severe malaria, many of which are seen in complicated cases of Plasmodium falciparum infection.

 

Option A. Blood glucose <40 mg/dL: Severe hypoglycemia is a known complication of severe malaria, particularly in patients treated with quinine.

 

Option C. Serum creatinine - 5.2: This indicates severe renal impairment. Serum creatinine levels above 3 mg/dL or reduced urine output despite rehydration are markers of severe malaria.

 

Option D. Unarousable coma: Cerebral malaria, which includes unarousable coma or seizures, is one of the most severe complications of Plasmodium falciparum infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnostic criteria for identifying complicated falciparum malaria, based on clinical and laboratory findings:

 

  1. Arterial pH: An arterial pH of less than 7.25 is indicative of complicated falciparum malaria.
  2. Bicarbonate Levels: A bicarbonate level of less than 15 is also a sign of complicated falciparum malaria.
  3. Base Deficit: A base deficit of more than 8 is another indicator of severe disease.
  4. Hemoglobin: A hemoglobin level of less than 5, or the presence of hemoglobinuria, are significant markers of severity.
  5. Venous Lactate: A venous lactate level of more than 5 further confirms the complexity and severity of the malaria infection.
  6. Blood Glucose: A blood glucose level less than 40 mg/dL is a critical indicator of complicated falciparum malaria.
  7. Creatinine Levels: A creatinine level exceeding 3 mg/dL points to significant renal impairment associated with severe malaria.
  8. Urine Output: A urine output of less than 400 mL per day, despite adequate rehydration with IV fluids, also signifies complicated falciparum malaria.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for an acute attack of cluster headache is: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subcutaneous sumatriptan

 

Subcutaneous sumatriptan is shown to be effective in treating acute attacks of cluster headaches. The reference indicates that oral sumatriptan is not effective, whereas subcutaneous sumatriptan has been proven beneficial. Intranasal sumatriptan and intranasal zolmitriptan also are shown to be effective.

 

Additionally, 100% oxygen therapy at a rate of at least 12 liters per minute is effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral sumatriptan: Oral sumatriptan has not been shown to be effective in treating acute cluster headache attacks.

 

Option C. 100% oxygen at 6 L/minute: Although 100% oxygen is a treatment option, the effective rate is at least 12 liters per minute, making 6 L/minute inadequate.

 

Option D. 100% oxygen at 8 L/minute: Similar to the previous option, 8 L/minute is below the effective rate of 12 liters per minute required for treating acute cluster headaches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment of choice for an acute attack of cluster headache is subcutaneous sumatriptan, and 100% oxygen therapy should be administered at a rate of at least 12 liters per minute for effectiveness.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with substernal chest discomfort. On examination, he was hypotensive, drowsy, and had unequal pulses. Which of the following investigations would be the best in this situation to ascertain the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trans-esophageal echocardiography

 

The presentation of acute chest pain, hypotension, drowsiness, and unequal pulses strongly suggests aortic dissection. Aortic dissection is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate diagnosis and management.

 

Trans-esophageal echocardiography (TEE) is highly sensitive and specific for diagnosing aortic dissection. It can be performed at the bedside, making it ideal for unstable patients. TEE provides detailed images of the aorta and can quickly confirm the presence of an intimal flap, a characteristic finding in aortic dissection.

 

If the patient has been stable, then preferred investigation of choice is CT angiography.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CXR PA view: A chest X-ray (CXR) might show a widened mediastinum, which can be a clue to aortic dissection, but it is not definitive. It lacks the sensitivity and specificity needed for a rapid and accurate diagnosis in an emergency setting.

 

Option C. MRI: While MRI can provide excellent detail, it is not suitable for acutely unstable patients due to the time required for the scan and the need to transport the patient to the MRI suite. It is not practical in an emergency setting.

 

Option D. Troponin assay: Troponin assays are used to diagnose myocardial infarction, not aortic dissection. Although troponins can be elevated in some cases of aortic dissection, they do not provide definitive diagnostic information about the dissection itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the setting of suspected aortic dissection, especially in an unstable patient, trans-esophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the best diagnostic tool due to its high sensitivity and ability to be performed at the bedside, providing rapid and accurate confirmation of the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic smoker came to the medicine outpatient department with complaints of upper chest discomfort and drooping of an eyelid. He also complained of pain radiating to the upper arm and a tingling sensation in the 4th and 5th digits of his left hand. The chest X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pancoast tumor

 

Pancoast tumors, also known as superior sulcus tumors, are a type of lung cancer located at the apex (top) of the lung. These tumors are particularly associated with several key clinical features and findings, especially in chronic smokers:

 

  1. Upper chest discomfort: This is a common symptom of a Pancoast tumor due to the tumor's location at the apex of the lung.
  2. Drooping of an eyelid (ptosis): This is part of Horner's syndrome, which occurs due to compression of the sympathetic nerves by the tumor. Horner's syndrome typically includes ptosis (drooping eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on the affected side of the face.
  3. Pain radiating to the upper arm and tingling sensation: These symptoms suggest involvement of the brachial plexus, a network of nerves that supplies the arm and hand. Pancoast tumors often invade or compress these nerves, leading to referred pain and sensory disturbances in the arm and hand.
  4. Chest X-ray findings: The provided chest X-ray shows a mass at the apex of the lung, which is characteristic of a Pancoast tumor.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Upper lobe pneumonia: While upper lobe pneumonia can cause chest discomfort and possibly pain, it is not associated with Horner's syndrome or brachial plexus involvement. The X-ray findings would also typically show consolidation rather than a mass.

 

Option C. Superior vena cava obstruction: This condition can cause swelling and discoloration of the face, neck, and upper extremities due to impaired blood flow. However, it does not explain the specific nerve-related symptoms like Horner's syndrome or tingling in the digits.

 

Option D. Aspergilloma: Aspergillomas are fungal balls that develop in pre-existing lung cavities, usually in patients with a history of tuberculosis or other lung diseases. They do not typically present with the neurological symptoms seen in this case, nor do they commonly cause Horner's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pancoast tumors, or superior sulcus tumors, are associated with upper chest discomfort, Horner's syndrome, and neurological symptoms in the arm due to their apical location and propensity to invade local structures such as the brachial plexus and sympathetic nerves.

questions.text: Low serum copper levels attributed to ATP7A gene is due to: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Menke’s disease

 

  • Menke's disease, also known as Menkes Kinky Hair syndrome, is caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene. This gene is crucial for the absorption and distribution of copper in the body. The mutation leads to reduced intestinal absorption of copper, resulting in low serum copper levels. This deficiency affects multiple systems, including neurodevelopment and connective tissue maintenance, often leading to severe developmental delay and life expectancy that rarely exceeds early childhood (Children die within 5 years). The condition is also associated with characteristic brittle, kinky hair, and growth retardation.
  • MCC: CVS-Aneurysmal dissection/Cardiac rupture

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dubin-Johnson syndrome: This is a liver disorder characterized by chronic jaundice and does not involve ATP7A or copper metabolism.

 

Option B. Wilson's disease: Although related to copper metabolism, Wilson's disease is due to mutations in the ATP7B gene, not ATP7A, leading to copper accumulation in tissues.

 

Option D. Gilbert's syndrome: This is a common hereditary condition that affects bilirubin metabolism, unrelated to copper levels or ATP7A.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Menke's disease is characterized by a genetic mutation in the ATP7A gene leading to poor copper absorption and severe systemic deficiencies, notable for its profound impact on early development and survival.

 

Reference - Harrison/Chap 333.

questions.text: Pulsus bisferiens is seen in which of the following conditions? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Aortic stenosis and aortic regurgitation

 

Explanation:

 

Pulsus bisferiens is characterized by a double systolic peak in the arterial pulse waveform. This finding is most commonly associated with:

 

  • Coexisting aortic stenosis and aortic regurgitation: The dual peak reflects the increased stroke volume and delayed ejection caused by these coexisting conditions.
  • Isolated severe aortic regurgitation or hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM): It can occasionally be observed in these conditions but is classically linked to the combination of aortic stenosis and regurgitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic stenosis: Incorrect because aortic stenosis alone is associated with pulsus parvus et tardus ('small and slow pulse') due to obstruction across the aortic valve, not pulsus bisferiens.

 

Option B. Aortic regurgitation: Incorrect because isolated aortic regurgitation typically causes a water hammer pulse (Corrigan pulse) rather than pulsus bisferiens.

 

Option D. Mitral regurgitation: Incorrect because the pulse in mitral regurgitation is hyperkinetic due to increased left ventricular preload but does not exhibit a double systolic peak.

 

Educational Objective:


Pulsus bisferiens, characterized by a double systolic peak, is most commonly associated with the combination of aortic stenosis and aortic regurgitation. Recognizing this pulse helps clinicians in diagnosing and assessing complex valvular pathologies.

choices.text: Renal artery stenosis

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of sudden onset headache, palpitations, and profuse sweating. The patient has had multiple similar episodes in the past. During these episodes, the patient's blood pressure is elevated. A 24-hour urinary metanephrine is elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pheochromocytoma

 

Pheochromocytoma is a rare tumor of the adrenal gland tissue. It results in the release of too much epinephrine and norepinephrine, hormones that control heart rate, metabolism, and blood pressure. The classic triad of symptoms includes:

 

  1. Headache: Sudden and severe headaches.
  2. Palpitations: Rapid heart rate.
  3. Profuse sweating: Excessive sweating.

 

In addition to these symptoms, patients with pheochromocytoma often experience episodic hypertension (elevated blood pressure). The diagnosis is confirmed by measuring elevated levels of urinary metanephrine, a metabolite of catecholamines.

 

TOC - Start with an alpha blocker, after 24 to 48 hours, add a beta blocker. The alpha blocker of choice is intravenous (IV) phentolamine. Phenoxybenzamine or prazosin can be used as alternative alpha blockers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Addison's disease: This condition results from adrenal insufficiency and typically presents with symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, and hyperpigmentation. Hypotension (low blood pressure) is more common, rather than hypertension.

 

Option B. Renal artery stenosis: This condition can cause secondary hypertension, but it does not present with the classic triad of headache, palpitations, and sweating. Additionally, it would not typically elevate urinary metanephrine.

 

Option D. Hyperthyroidism: This condition can cause symptoms like palpitations and sweating, but it would not cause episodic hypertension or elevated urinary metanephrine levels. Instead, hyperthyroidism is more associated with a consistently high heart rate and other systemic symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pheochromocytoma presents with the classic triad of headache, palpitations, and sweating, along with episodic hypertension and elevated urinary metanephrine levels.

questions.text: A lady with mitral stenosis who is bedridden, develops sudden onset shortness of breath. On examination, she has a swollen red limb with pain in the calf. What is the clinical diagnosis?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pulmonary embolism

 

Explanation

 

The patient, who is bedridden with mitral stenosis, presents with sudden onset shortness of breath and a swollen, red limb with calf pain. These clinical features strongly suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The sudden shortness of breath indicates that a thrombus from the DVT has likely embolized to the lungs, causing a pulmonary embolism. This is a common and potentially life-threatening complication in bedridden patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pulmonary edema: This is characterized by fluid accumulation in the lungs, typically secondary to heart failure, and does not present with a swollen, red limb or calf pain.

 

Option C. Cerebral embolism: This would present with neurological deficits, not shortness of breath and a swollen, red limb.

 

Option D. Paradoxical embolism: This occurs when a thrombus passes from the venous to the arterial system through a cardiac shunt (e.g., patent foramen ovale). While this could be considered if there were signs of arterial embolism, the presentation here is more consistent with pulmonary embolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulmonary embolism should be suspected in bedridden patients presenting with sudden onset shortness of breath and clinical signs of deep vein thrombosis, such as a swollen, red, painful limb.

choices.text: Interstitial lung disease
Scleroderma renal crisis

questions.text: Which among the following is more common in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis when compared to diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Esophageal dysmotility

 

Esophageal dysmotility is more commonly associated with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc), particularly as part of the CREST syndrome (Calcinosis, Raynaud's phenomenon, Esophageal dysmotility, Sclerodactyly, and Telangiectasia). This condition involves abnormalities in the motility of the esophagus, which can lead to difficulties in swallowing and gastroesophageal reflux.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Myopathy: While myopathy can occur in systemic sclerosis, it is not specifically more common in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis compared to the diffuse type.

 

Option C. Interstitial lung disease (ILD): ILD is actually more commonly associated with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis due to broader and more aggressive skin involvement and higher prevalence of specific autoantibodies like Anti-Scl-70 (anti-topoisomerase).

 

Option D. Scleroderma renal crisis: This is a severe complication more frequently seen in diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis, particularly in the early stages of the disease, often exacerbated by the use of corticosteroids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/ Chap 360

questions.text: Which of the following connective tissue degradation disorder is associated with aortic aneurysm? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Marfan's Syndrome

 

Marfan's Syndrome is a connective tissue disorder that affects the body's connective tissues, which provide structural support to various organs and tissues. It is particularly associated with cardiovascular complications, including aortic aneurysms and dissections. This is due to the weakening of the aortic wall caused by defective fibrillin-1, a glycoprotein essential for the elasticity and strength of the connective tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome: While Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS) can lead to vascular complications, including aortic aneurysms, it is specifically the vascular type (Type IV) of EDS that is associated with these issues. However, Marfan's Syndrome is more commonly linked to aortic aneurysms.

 

Option C. Atherosclerosis: Atherosclerosis is a condition characterized by the build-up of plaque within the arterial walls, leading to narrowing and hardening of the arteries. It is a risk factor for abdominal aortic aneurysm but is not classified as a connective tissue disorder.

 

Option D. Scurvy: Scurvy is caused by a deficiency in vitamin C, leading to defective collagen synthesis. While it results in symptoms like mucosal bleeding and poor wound healing, it is not associated with aortic aneurysms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marfan's Syndrome is a connective tissue disorder closely associated with the development of aortic aneurysms due to the defective fibrillin-1 protein affecting the structural integrity of the aortic wall.

questions.text: An HIV patient presents with fever and neck stiffness. Lumbar puncture was done and CSF examination shows lymphocytosis, normal glucose, increased protein and positive India ink staining. What is likely causative organism? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cryptococcus neoformans

 

Explanation

 

The correct answer is Cryptococcus neoformans. The patient presents with signs of meningitis (fever, neck stiffness) and has a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) profile showing lymphocytosis, normal glucose, increased protein, and positive India ink staining.

 

Cryptococcal meningitis is a common opportunistic infection in HIV patients and is diagnosed by the presence of encapsulated yeast cells seen on India ink staining.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pneumocystis jirovecii: This organism typically causes pneumonia rather than meningitis.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis: Tuberculous meningitis usually presents with low glucose levels in the CSF, which is not the case here.

 

Option D. Pneumococcus: Pneumococcal meningitis typically presents with a neutrophilic CSF rather than lymphocytic CSF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptococcus neoformans is a common cause of meningitis in HIV patients, characterized by lymphocytic CSF, normal glucose, increased protein, and positive India ink staining, which reveals encapsulated yeast cells. ​

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with an acute ischemic stroke is undergoing thrombolysis with IV alteplase. He currently weighs 80 kg. What is the appropriate dose of alteplase to be given to this patient? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 8 mg

 

The appropriate dose of IV alteplase (recombinant tissue plasminogen activator, rtPA) for a patient with acute ischemic stroke is 0.9 mg/kg. The total dose for an 80 kg patient would be approximately 72 mg (0.9 mg/kg x 80 kg = 72 mg). According to the standard administration protocol:

 

  • 10% of the total dose is given as an initial bolus over 1 minute.
  • The remaining 90% is infused over 1 hour.

 

For this patient:

 

  • Total dose = 72 mg.
  • Bolus dose = 10% of 72 mg = 7.2 mg, rounded to 8 mg.
  • The remaining dose (64.8 mg ≈ 64 mg) is given as a continuous infusion over 1 hour.

 

Thus, the initial bolus dose of alteplase for this patient is 8 mg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient weighing 80 kg, the appropriate initial bolus dose of alteplase for acute ischemic stroke is 8 mg, followed by the remainder of the dose given as an infusion over 1 hour.

questions.text: A person presents to the hospital with fever and chills. Fever profile is ordered and is found to be negative for malaria and dengue. RK-39 test is found to be positive. What is the treatment of choice? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amphotericin B

 

The RK-39 test is used to diagnose visceral leishmaniasis, which is also known as kala-azar. Visceral leishmaniasis is caused by the Leishmania parasite and is transmitted by the bite of infected sandflies. The test detects antibodies against the RK-39 antigen, which is a marker for this disease.

 

In India, the first-line treatment for visceral leishmaniasis is Amphotericin B. This drug is effective in treating the disease and is preferred due to its ability to clear the infection. While other treatments like sodium stibogluconate are available, Amphotericin B is the standard treatment due to its efficacy and safety profile in the Indian context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Griseofulvin: This is an antifungal medication used to treat dermatophyte infections of the skin, hair, and nails. It is not effective against parasitic infections like leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Dapsone: This drug is primarily used to treat leprosy and certain types of dermatitis. It is not used for treating leishmaniasis.

 

Option D. Hydroxychloroquine: This medication is used for the treatment of malaria, rheumatoid arthritis, and lupus erythematosus. It is not effective against leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The RK-39 test is used to diagnose visceral leishmaniasis, and the treatment of choice for visceral leishmaniasis in India is Amphotericin B

questions.text: A hypertensive patient who is non-compliant with medication presents to you with sudden onset breathlessness. A chest X-ray was done, which is shown below. How will you manage this patient? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Intravenous nitroglycerin

 

The patient presents with symptoms and signs indicative of pulmonary edema, which is evident from the chest X-ray showing interstitial edema and classic bat-wing appearance, suggestive of cardiogenic pulmonary edema. The history of hypertension and non-compliance with medication supports the diagnosis, as poorly controlled hypertension can lead to increased afterload, left ventricular failure, and subsequent pulmonary edema.

 

Intravenous nitroglycerin: Nitroglycerin is the treatment of choice in this scenario as it helps to reduce both preload and afterload by dilating veins and arteries. This leads to a reduction in pulmonary congestion and improvement in symptoms of breathlessness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous salbutamol: Salbutamol is a bronchodilator used primarily in the treatment of asthma or COPD exacerbations, and primarily not used intravenously. It is not indicated for managing pulmonary edema and does not address the underlying cause of fluid accumulation in the lungs.

 

Option C. Nebulization with salbutamol: Similar to intravenous salbutamol, nebulized salbutamol is used for bronchodilation in conditions like asthma or COPD. It is not effective in treating pulmonary edema and does not relieve the symptoms caused by fluid overload in the lungs.

 

Option D. Oxygen and antibiotics: While oxygen might be necessary to support the patient’s respiratory status, antibiotics are not indicated unless there is a concurrent infection, which is not suggested by the patient’s presentation. The primary issue here is fluid overload due to heart failure, not an infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of cardiogenic pulmonary edema, intravenous nitroglycerin is essential to reduce preload and afterload, thereby alleviating pulmonary congestion and improving the patient's symptoms.

questions.text: A patient presented with strong upper limb pulses and weak lower limb pulses with chest x-ray showing rib notching. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coarctation of Aorta

 

The classic presentation of coarctation of the aorta, a congenital condition characterized by the narrowing of the aorta. This narrowing typically occurs just after the arteries that branch off to the upper body, leading to a disparity in blood flow and pressure between the upper and lower parts of the body.

 

Key indicators in this case include:

 

  1. Strong upper limb pulses and weak lower limb pulses: The narrowing restricts blood flow to the lower extremities, causing the upper body to receive a higher volume of blood, which results in stronger pulses in the upper limbs compared to the lower limbs.
  2. Chest x-ray showing rib notching: Rib notching is a result of enlarged intercostal arteries that form collateral pathways to bypass the narrowed aorta. These arteries erode the underside of the ribs over time, creating a notched appearance on chest x-rays.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transposition of great vessels: This condition involves the switching of the major arteries (the aorta and the pulmonary artery) from their normal positions. It does not present with rib notching or a difference in pulse strength between the upper and lower limbs.

 

Option C. Tetralogy of Fallot: This is a combination of four heart defects, including a ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, and an overriding aorta. It primarily presents with cyanosis and does not typically involve rib notching or differential limb pulses.

 

Option D. Ebstein’s anomaly: This is a rare heart defect affecting the tricuspid valve and right ventricle. It does not cause rib notching or a significant difference in pulse strength between upper and lower limbs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coarctation of the aorta is identified by the presence of strong upper limb pulses, weak lower limb pulses, and rib notching on a chest x-ray, which is caused by collateral circulation developing around the narrowed section of the aorta.

questions.text: A patient comes to the hospital within 3 hours of the onset of chest pain. ECG revealed ST depression in anterior chest leads and T wave inversion. She could be best managed by? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Aspirin with heparin

 

The description of diffuse symmetric TWI without ST elevations is consistent with NSTEMI which is characterized by subtotal platelet-rich thrombosis + distal phasic embolization. NSTEMI treated with DAPT+LMWH followed by CAG for risk stratification

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PCI is treatment of choice for STEMI.

 

Option B. Arrhythmia prophylaxis is not the definitive best management strategy

 

Option C. Thrombolysis/Fibrinolytics have no role in the management of NSTEMI

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/ACS/Chap 277

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is found to be positive for HBsAg and HBeAg and is diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B. The viral load of the patient was 2 x 10^5 IU/mL and ALT is found to be doubled. What is the appropriate management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tenofovir

 

The patient is diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B, as indicated by the positive HBsAg and HBeAg, which are markers of infection and infectivity, respectively. The viral load of 2 x 105 IU/mL and elevated ALT levels suggest active viral replication and liver inflammation.

 

HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): This is a marker of infection. Its presence indicates that the person is infectious.

 

HBeAg (Hepatitis B e antigen): This is a marker of infectivity. It indicates that the virus is replicating and the patient is highly infectious.

 

HBV DNA: This is a marker of viral replication. In chronic hepatitis B, a high level of HBV DNA correlates with an increased risk of complications such as cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

The decision to start treatment in chronic hepatitis B is primarily based on the levels of HBV DNA and ALT. According to guidelines, treatment is indicated if:

 

  1. HBV DNA is more than 2000 IU/mL.
  2. ALT is elevated (more than 2 to 3 times the upper limit of normal).

 

In this patient, both criteria are met.

 

Tenofovir is preferred for its efficacy and lower risk of resistance compared to other options like lamivudine. Tenofovir is also favored over interferon-based therapies due to better durability of response and lower side effect profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lamivudine: This drug is no longer preferred due to a high risk of resistance.

 

Option C. Peg IFN for 52 weeks: Pegylated interferon is not preferred due to less favorable response rates and a higher side effect profile compared to tenofovir.

 

Option D. Combined peg IFN with lamivudine: Combination therapy with pegylated interferon and lamivudine is not recommended due to increased side effects and no significant improvement in efficacy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tenofovir is the preferred treatment for chronic hepatitis B with high viral load and elevated ALT levels due to its efficacy and lower risk of resistance.

choices.text: Assertion and reason are true and reason is the correct explanation of assertion
Assertion and reason are true but reason is not the correct explanation of assertion
Assertion is true, reason is false
Assertion is false, reason is true

questions.text:
Assertion: Myocarditis is seen as a complication of diphtheria.


Reason: It is due to bacteremia.  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Assertion is true, reason is false

 

Explanation:

 

The assertion that myocarditis is seen as a complication of diphtheria is correct. Myocarditis is a well-known and serious complication of diphtheria, often leading to significant morbidity and mortality.

 

The reason provided, that myocarditis is due to bacteremia, is incorrect. The complications of diphtheria, including myocarditis, are primarily due to the effects of the diphtheria toxin (toxemia), not bacteremia. The toxin affects various organs, including the heart, leading to myocarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myocarditis is a complication of diphtheria caused by the diphtheria toxin (toxemia), not by bacteremia.

questions.text: The four-layer suture repair of an inguinal hernia with double breasting of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal is known as: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Shouldice operation

 

Explanation:

 

The Shouldice operation is specifically characterized as a four-layer herniorrhaphy technique that involves double breasting of the conjoint tendon, inguinal ligament, and the two halves of the fascia transversalis to create a reinforced posterior wall repair. This multi-layered approach creates a strong repair using local tissues without mesh.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Lichtenstein operation: This is a tension-free hernioplasty that uses a polypropylene mesh placed on top of the posterior wall (onlay repair). It does not involve double breasting of local tissues or a four-layer repair.
  • Option C. Stoppa operation: This is a preperitoneal mesh repair technique primarily used for complex or recurrent hernias. It involves placing a large mesh in the preperitoneal space, not a four-layer tissue repair.
  • Option D. Bassini repair: While this is also a herniorrhaphy technique, it involves suturing the conjoint tendon to the inguinal ligament using interrupted sutures. It does not include the four-layer double breasting technique that defines the Shouldice repair.

 

Comparison of hernia repair techniques:

  • Herniorrhaphy: Strengthening of the posterior wall using locally available tissue 
    • Bassini: Simple suturing of conjoint tendon to inguinal ligament
    • Shouldice: Double-breasting with 4-layer posterior wall repair
    • Desarda: Uses a strip of external oblique aponeurosis
  • Hernioplasty: Use of prosthetic material (mesh) 
    • Lichtenstein: Onlay mesh repair

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Shouldice repair is distinguished by its meticulous four-layer closure technique with double-breasting of the posterior wall tissues, creating a strong anatomical repair without the use of prosthetic material.
